courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Renewable Energy Technologies
courses.description: The effort of securing more sustainable, reliable, and affordable energy supplies is among the most challenges faced in this century. This course focuses on scientific and engineering fundamentals of renewable energy resources and conversion technologies. The subject-specific lectures will be provided in more depth to cover these topics: global energy sources, thermodynamics for renewable energy, solar energy, wind energy, hydro power, bioenergy, geothermal, fuel cell, and design, modeling and analysis of energy systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENER2020.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated by course evaluation done by students.
courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Aldo Vieira da Rosa (2009). Fundamentals of renewable energy processes (2nd ed.), Burlington, MA: Academic Press.
(2) G.N. Tiwari and M.K. Ghosal (2007). Fundamentals of renewable energy sources, Oxford, U.K.: Alpha Science International Ltd.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Energy and Environmental Economics and Management
courses.description:
This course aims to provide students with an introduction to economic principles that pertain to energy and environment. The objective is to apply economics to particular issues of energy markets, energy planning and demand management, government regulations and policies, environmental impact and conservation, local pollution control, and new technologies.

The course will cover fundamental concepts in economics including utility and preference, supply and demand functions, cost-benefit analysis and market equilibrium, project evaluation and management, externality, and game theory. Through this course, the students will understand the interactions and possible externalities between energy, environment, economy, and sustainability. The students will acquire skills in conducting energy and carbon auditing, and also learn how to analyze the effects of government policies and regulations on energy demand and supply, prices, carbon emissions, to name a few.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated by course evaluation done by students.
courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) W D Nordhaus. The Climate Casino: Risk, Uncertainty, and Economics for a Warming World. Yale University Press, 2013.
(2) N G Mankiw. Principles of Economics. Cengage Learning, 2014.
(3) J Hirshleifer, A Glazer, etc. Price Theory and Applications: Decisions, Markets, and Information. Cambridge University Press, 2005.
(4) S. S. Rao. Engineering Optimization: Theory and Practice. John Wiley & Sons, 2019.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Heating, Ventilation, and Air-Conditioning (HVAC) I
courses.description: This course introduces the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems for buildings. The contents include psychrometrics, air-handling process, zones, single-zone system, constant air volume (CAV) systems, variable air volume (VAV) systems, hydronic system and architecture, central plant, thermal comfort, ventilation and indoor air quality.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR2404.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated by course evaluation done by students.
courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings: (1) R. McDowall, Fundamentals of HVAC Systems, Elsevier, 2008

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Engineering Practicum
courses.description: The course combines activities designed to develop employability with the knowledge and skills gained through attending workshops or seminars. Successful completion of the course will provide students with the employability skills required for transition to the world of work. Students who have attended certain industrial and professional workshops or seminars required by the EEEN programme may be able to count these towards the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated by course evaluation done by students.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Heating, Ventilation, and Air-Conditioning (HVAC) II
courses.description: This course introduces the control strategies of the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems, including introduction to building automation, control of CAV systems, VAV systems, chilled water systems, chillers, cooling towers, design and control, control devices and BAS. This course also introduces thermal insulation, heating and cooling load calculations, ventilation and infiltration.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: EEEN2040 / ESTR2404 and MAEG2030 / ESTR2402 or with the consent of the course instructor
Not for students who have taken ESTR3410.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

(2) ASHRAE Handbook.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Energy Utilization and Human Behaviour
courses.description: This course emphasizes the intersection between energy consumption and human/corporate/economic activities. The course follows a grid structure in its organisation. The grid’s horizontal lines are about energy consumption, involving electricity use, and direct burning of fuels including combustion engines, boilers, stoves, etc. The vertical lines are about human activities, involving major economic sectors including the industrial, transport, commercial, and residential ones. The intersections between the grid’s horizontal lines and vertical lines are the lecture topics. Each lecture has discussion over three aspects: (1) how energy is utilized; (2) what factors are affecting energy consumption in intensity and in total; and (3) how human behaviour could be changed for energy conservation and pollution control.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR3400
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

courses.recommended_readings:

(2) Fred Bosselman, "Energy, Economics and the Environment, 3d: 3rd Edition", July 2010, Foundation Press. (ISBN: 1599417227)
(3) Carol A. Dahl , "International Energy Markets: Understanding Pricing, Policies and Profits", April 2004, PennWell Corporation (ISBN:0878147993)
(4) David JC Mackay, “Sustainable Energy Energy – without the hot air” UIT Cambridge, 2009.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Engineering Materials

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

courses.description: This course introduces fundamentals of materials including atomic bonding; crystal structures, defects; mechanical properties of materials, phase diagram; overview of metals, alloys, ceramics, polymers, semiconductors and composites; electrical, optical, magnetic, and thermal properties of materials; materials selection and design considerations for engineering technologies. Applications of materials to energy and environmental engineering, mechanical engineering, medical engineering, and others will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENER3030 or ESTR3402.

courses.recommended_readings:

(2) M. J . Schulz, A. D . Kelkar, and M. J. Sundaresan, Nanoengineering of Structural, Functional and Smart Materials, CRC Press 2005.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Kinetic Energy Harvesting Devices and Systems

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

courses.description: In this course, we will discuss kinetic energy harvesting devices and systems, from basic mechanisms to applications. The first half semester of this course will start with talking about the fundaments of kinetic energy harvesting, including mechanisms of electromagnetic, piezoelectric, triboelectric, electrostatic, and others. And then it will cover basic device designs and energy transfer; physics and circuit models; electromechanical modeling and analysis; simulation methods and practice; and interfacing circuits. The second half semester will cover the applications of kinetic energy harvesting in various situations, including power plants, wind turbine, vibrations, hydro system, ocean waves, body motions and others, and ends with discussions on kinetic energy harvesting technology in the future. The evaluation will be based on final project, midterm exam, homework, lab report, and participation in class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENER4010 or ESTR4400.

(2) Shashank Priya, Daniel J. Inman, Energy Harvesting Technologies, ISBN 978-0-387-76463-4, Springer, 2009
(3) D. Spreemann and Y. Manoli, Electromagnetic Vibration Energy Harvesting Devices, ISBN 978-94-007-2944-5, Springer, 2012
(4) A. Erturk, D. J. Inman, Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting, 978-11-199-9115-1 Wiley, 2011
(5) Philippe Basset, Elena Blokhina, Dimitri Galayko, Electrostatic Kinetic Energy Harvesting, ISBN 978-1-84821-716-4, ISTE Ltd and John Wiley & Sons, Inc., 2016
(6) Z.L. Wang, L. Lin, J. Chen, S. Niu, Y. Zi, Triboelectric Nanogenerators, ISBN 978-3-319-40038-9, Springer, 2016

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Solar Energy and Photovoltaic Technology

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

courses.description: This course provides students with knowledge of solar energy and photovoltaic technologies. It covers the following topics: introduction to solar energy technologies, semiconductors for photovoltaics; working principle and performance evaluation of photovoltaic cells (PVs); photovoltaic technologies (crystalline PVs, thin film PVs, and organic and nanostructure based PVs), solar panel system design, cost aspects, and market development and environmental impact of photovoltaic industry.

Not for students who have taken ESTR4402
Pre-requisite(s):

2. ELEG2202 and ELEG3201/ESTR3200

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Nuclear Energy and Risk Assessment
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic nuclear physics - elementary quantum theory; nuclear forces; shell structure of the nucleus; alpha, beta, and gamma radioactive decays; nuclear reactions; fission and fusion. In addition, this course will discuss the nuclear power plant design - nuclear power plant layout; reactor dynamics; reactor start up and process control, waste treatment. Risk management - assessment and management of nuclear safety, radiation, exposure and environment, safety assessment will be introduced in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENER4030 or ESTR4404.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:

(2) Kenneth D. Kok, “Nuclear Engineering Handbook”, June 2009, CRC Press (ISBN: 1420053906)
(3) John C. Lee, Norman J. McCormick , “Risk and Safety Analysis of Nuclear Systems”, July 2011, Wiley, John & Sons (ISBN: 0470907568)

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Energy Storage Devices and Systems

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description: This course describes the fundamental principles, device and system design of energy storage technologies including electrochemical energy storage (batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells etc.), thermal energy storage (phase change), mechanical energy storage (flywheel and compressed air energy storage), hydrogen storage. The applications of energy storage technologies in supporting renewable energy sources for smart grid, hybrid and all-electric vehicles, and green building applications will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite(s): ENER2010 and ENER2020, or EEEN2020, or with the consent of the course instructor.
Not for students who have taken ENER4040, ENER4050, ESTR4406 or ESTR4422.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

(2) A. J. Bard and L. R. Faulkner, Electrochemical Methods: Fundamentals and Applications, John Wiley & Sons New York, 2001.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Energy Distribution

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 713
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 713

courses.description: This course will introduce electric power system fundamentals, control, and operation. The course will discuss power system components and overview, review of basic circuit elements, AC circuit analysis and phasor representation, complex power, active and reactive power, power factor and power triangle, reactive power compensation, balanced 3-phase system analysis, Yconnection and delta-connection, transformer modelling and analysis, per-unit analysis, transient stability and analysis, voltage stability and control, frequency stability and control, power flow analysis, economic dispatching, optimal power flow problem, power plant planning, smart grid, energy storage system, renewable generation and utilization, and electric vehicle integration.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite(s): ELEG2202
Not for students who have taken ENER4040, ENER4060, ESTR4406 or ESTR4424
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated by course evaluation done by students.
courses.required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) J. D. Glover, M. S. Sarma, T. J. Overbye, Power System Analysis and Design (the 5th edition), Cengage Learning, 2011
(2) Allen J. Wood, Bruce F. Wollenberg, Gerald B. Sheblé, Power Generation, Operation and Control (the 3rd edition), Wiley-Interscience, 2013

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Green Building and Sustainable Technologies

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description: This course introduces technologies, strategies as well as management and assessment systems to improve sustainability of buildings in relation to their environmental impacts. Applications such as passive design strategies, energy efficient systems, renewable energy and building information modelling are illustrated for enhancing the building performance and fulfilling green building assessment criteria and related regulations. The course will also enable students to adopt a lifecycle assessment approach to analyze building environmental performances and tackle with concurrent environmental issues for the target of local and global carbon neutrality.
courses.course_syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

(2) BEAM Plus for New Buildings Version 1.2. http://www.hkgbc.org.hk/eng/BEAMPlus.aspx
(3) LEED Green Building Rating System http://www.usgbc.org/leed
(4) CASBEE (Comprehensive Assessment System for Built Environment Efficiency), Japan, www.ibec.or.jp/CASBEE/
(5) Buildings Energy Efficiency Ordinance (Cap. 610) https://www.emsd.gov.hk/beeo/

(7) ASCE, 2015. Building Information Modeling: Applications and Practices, American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Reston, Virginia.

courses.subject: EEEN
courses.title: Final Year Project I
courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to carry out, under the supervision of an academic staff, an independent project with research elements in engineering.
courses.course_syllabus: The course includes, but is not limited to, the following elements: literature review, modelling, system design and implementation, project evaluation.
courses.required_readings: Literature review materials will be recommended by the project supervisor.
